CSpreselection:
Public Campaigning

By “public campaigning” we mean focused communication initiatives that aim to influence the public’s opinions, attitudes and behaviour on intelligence-related issues. The primary target group is the general public.
CScampimpact2: Greater interest in interoperability of EU JHA databases, in the ways in which travel surveillance and migration policy are promoting systems of generalised surveillance, concern about the possible use of underhand tactics to undermine migrant solidarity and NGOs at sea, concerns about AI and facial recognition are currently hot topics, like in the Reclaim your Face campaign.
CSprotectleg1:
Always 

(There is almost always reason to be concerned about surveillance)
CSprotectleg2no: I assume I am always liable to be intercepted when working on sensitive matters; I do not have great technical know-how or the ability or time to train up on these issues, but I do follow the line when I am told something amounts to a minimum standard I should use. I feel that extreme openness in everything I do amounts to a form of defence, because it is all done as a form of public service, including when criticising malfunctions and/or irregularities and foul play.
CSattitude1: Intelligence agencies contradict democratic principles, and their powers should be kept at a bare minimum.
CSattitude2: Effective intelligence oversight is a hopeless endeavour and even a systematic reorganization is unlikely to ensure misconduct is uncovered and prevented.

CSpreselection:
Policy Advocacy

By “policy advocacy” we mean systematic attempts to influence politicians and institutions in their decision-making processes on intelligence-related issues. The primary target group is regulatory bodies and policy makers.
CSadvocact1[SQ01]: Submissions to EU (and to a lesser extent national/EU MSs) bodies, esp. the EP (LIBE Ctee)
CSadvocact1[SQ02]: Academic and semi-academic studies, reports, papers and blogs
CSadvocimpact2: One very recent example: In the autumn of last year (2020), Prof. Ian Brown and I (Douwe Korff) submitted two extensive papers on the inadequacy of UK data protection law, in particular in relation to access to data by the UK intelligence services, to EU bodies involved in assessing the adequacy of UK data protection law after Brexit. Our very critical comments were very clearly reflected (at times verbatim) in the EP LIBE Ctee draft resolution on the issue (to go to the EP plenary in May) and in the EDPB's opinion on UK adequacy (issued earlier this month [April] 2021).
CSprotectops4: Under the current conditions of communications surveillance, technological solutions cannot offer sufficient protection for the data I handle.
CSprotectleg2no: If the intelligence agencies want to, I am sure they can access my data and communications - both legally and illegally. I just shrug that off.
CSattitude1: Intelligence agencies are necessary and legitimate institutions of democratic states, even though they may sometimes overstep their legal mandates.
CSattitude2: Intelligence oversight lacks efficacy, hence a fundamental reorganization of oversight capacity is needed for oversight practitioners to reliably uncover past misconduct and prevent future misconduct.

CSpreselection:
Policy Advocacy

By “policy advocacy” we mean systematic attempts to influence politicians and institutions in their decision-making processes on intelligence-related issues. The primary target group is regulatory bodies and policy makers.
CSadvocact1[SQ01]: Lobbying parliament for and during legal reforms, including drafting amendments
CSadvocact1[SQ02]: Engagement with oversight bodies throug workshops

CSprotectops4: Technological tools help to protect my identity to some extent, but an attacker with sufficient power may eventually be able to bypass my technological safeguards.
CSprotectleg1:
Sometimes 

(From time to time, there is reason to be concerned about surveillance)
CSprotectleg2no: CSOs are not generally covered by protected communicaitons, like journalists or lawyers, or even trade unionists. Most of the work of local CSOs is harmless enough not to require surveillance. International work is different. For example, advocacy work on international trade issues is a legitimate target for US security services tasked by the US Trade Representative (Knowledge Ecology International case). But in most cases the main surveillance risk to my activities comes from governments of less democratic countries where project partners are based.
CSattitude1: Intelligence agencies contradict democratic principles, and their powers should be kept at a bare minimum.
CSattitude2: Intelligence oversight lacks efficacy, hence a fundamental reorganization of oversight capacity is needed for oversight practitioners to reliably uncover past misconduct and prevent future misconduct.

Strategic Litigation

By “strategic litigation” we mean the targeted use of legal proceedings aimed at advancing the common good or at protecting basic rights that are deemed to be insufficiently addressed in legal frameworks related to intelligence. The primary target group is courts.
CSlitigateact1[SQ02]: Bulk Personal Datasets & Bulk Communications Data (UK)
CSlitigateact1[SQ03]: PRIVACY INTERNATIONAL and Others against the United Kingdom (ECHR, Application no. 46259/16)

Policy Advocacy

By “policy advocacy” we mean systematic attempts to influence politicians and institutions in their decision-making processes on intelligence-related issues. The primary target group is regulatory bodies and policy makers.
CSadvocact1[SQ01]: Research reports on regulation of algorithmic tools by police/intelligence agencies
CSadvocact1[SQ02]: contributing to research on algorithmic bias
CSadvocact1[SQ03]: internal governance and oversight of development and deployment of algorithmic surveillance tools
CSadvocact1[SQ04]: building a data ethics framework for law enforcement
CSadvocact1[SQ05]: encouraging greater transparency and independent oversight as a way of demonstrating legitimacy
CSadvocimpact2: independent reports are now frequently cited in official reports and policy papers.
